t: Job 41
Can*pn you pull in Leviathan with a hook or*ln tie his tongue down with a rope?
Can*ln you put a cord through his nose or*ln pierce his jaw with a hook?
Will*ln he beg you for mercy or*ln speak softly to you?
Will*ln he make a covenant with you so*ln that you can take him as a slave forever?
Can*ln you play with him like a bird or*ln put him on a leash for your girls?
Will*ln traders bargain for him or*ln divide him among the merchants?
Can*ln you fill his hide with harpoons or*ln his head with fishing spears?
Lay*ln a hand on him. You*ln will remember the battle and*ln never repeat it!
Any*ln hope of capturing him proves false. Does*ln a person not collapse at the very sight of him?
No*ln one is ferocious enough to rouse Leviathan; who*ln then can stand against me?
Who*ln confronted me, that I should repay him? Everything*ln under heaven belongs to me.
I*pn cannot be silent about his limbs, his*ln power, and his graceful proportions.
Who*ln can strip off his outer covering? Who*ln can penetrate his double layer of armor?
Who*ln can open his jaws, surrounded*ln by those terrifying teeth?
His*ln pride is in his rows of scales, closely*ln sealed together.
One*ln scale is so close to another that*ln no air can pass between them.
They*ln are joined to one another, so*ln closely connected they cannot be separated.
His*ln snorting flashes with light, while*ln his eyes are like the rays of dawn.
Flaming*ln torches shoot from his mouth; fiery*ln sparks fly out!
Smoke*ln billows from his nostrils as*ln from a boiling pot or burning reeds.
His*ln breath sets coals ablaze, and*ln flames pour out of his mouth.
Strength*ln resides in his neck, and*ln dismay dances before him.
The*ln folds of his flesh are joined together, solid*ln as metal and immovable.
His*ln heart is as hard as a rock, as*ln hard as a lower millstone!
When*ln Leviathan rises, the mighty are terrified; they*ln withdraw because of his thrashing.
The*ln sword that reaches him will have no effect, nor*ln will a spear, dart, or arrow.
He*ln regards iron as straw, and*ln bronze as rotten wood.
No*ln arrow can make him flee; slingstones*ln become like stubble to him.
A*ln club is regarded as stubble, and*ln he laughs at the sound of a javelin.
His*ln undersides are jagged potsherds, spreading*ln the mud like a threshing sledge.
He*ln makes the depths seethe like a cauldron; he*ln makes the sea like an ointment jar.
He*ln leaves a shining wake behind him; one*ln would think the deep had gray hair!
He*ln has no equal on earth — a*ln creature devoid of fear!
He*ln surveys everything that is haughty; he*ln is king over all the proud beasts.
